trial_identification.studytitle: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) weaning trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) weaning trial to determine the most efficient method in weaning babies less than 30 weeks gestational age "OFF" CPAP.
trial_identification.secondaryid: CPAP weaning trial follow up phase

conditions.healthcondition: Babies who are on constant continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) support need to have the CPAP weaned in order to allow the babies to breathe without support.

interventions.interventions: This trial will look at 3 methods of weaning CPAP. Method 1. When the baby has reached the stability criteria they will be taken OFF CPAP. Method 2. When the baby has reached the stability criteria they will be gradually taken OFF CPAP from 30 minutes to completely OFF . Method 3. When the baby has reached the stability criteria they will be gradually taken OFF CPAP from 30 minutes to completely OFF as in method 2, but when the baby is having time OFF CPAP they will have supplemental air or oxygen via a nasal cannula at 0.5 L/min

primaryOutcome.outcome: Reduction in time of respiratory support. For methods 1 and 2 this will be 24 hours "OFF" CPAP and for those in method 3, this will be 24 hours "OFF" nasal cannula. So the time on CPAP will be from the time commenced CPAP to "OFF" support.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Reduction in Chronic Lung Disease (CLD) rate defined as requiring oxygen at 36 weeks post conceptional age

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1.All babies <30 weeks gestational age 2.On CPAP for >24 hours 3.Babies either extubated to CPAP or as a primary treatment for respiratory distress Criteria for commencing weaning: Babies must have all of the following for the past 12 hours:- 1.CPAP <6 cm H2O 2.Oxygen requirement less than 26% and not increasing 3.RR less than 60 4.No significant chest recession 5.Less than 3 episodes of mild self reverting apnoeas and/or bradycardias and/or desaturations in 1 hour for the previous 6 hours 6.Average saturation above 87% most of the time and/or transcutaneous (TcPO2)/arterial PaO2 >50 mm Hg. 7.Tolerates nose rests well during nursing cares 8.Not treated for patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) or sepsis Criteria for failed trial OFF at least 2 of the following:- 1.Increase work of breathing (Intercostal recession and accessory muscles contributing for respiration) with RR >75 for >1 hour 2.Increased apnoeas and/or bradycardias and/or desaturations >2 in previous 1 hour 3.Major apnoea or bradycardia requiring more sustained stimulation/ resuscitation 4.Increased O2 requirement >25% with average saturation <85% and/or TcPO2/PaO2 <45mmHg 5.pH of <7.2 6.PaCO2 of > 65 mmHg. The babies will be put back on CPAP if failed trial OFF CPAP. If a baby has a major apnoea and/or bradycardia requiring resuscitation they may require intubation and ventilation.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. If congenital respiratory abnormality including central and anatomical.

trial_design.concealment: The randomisation will now be web based where investigators will log into the CPAP weaning trial web site (TREONIC WEB SITE) and once logged in will be able to randomise babies to a specific group.
trial_design.sequence: Permuted block randomisation. The babies will be stratified into 2 gestational age (GA) categories. One category will be babies < 27 weeks GA and the second category will be babies 27-29 weeks GA.
trial_design.designfeatures: If the babies fail time OFF CPAP they will return to the same CPAP weaning group. We will review the data after 90 babies have been enrolled.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Many small babies <30 weeks gestational age have a very immature respiratory system and require respiratory support for a limited period of time until they mature and can breath by themselves. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is one such method by which support can be given to these immature babies to allow them to breath without being put on a ventilator or breathing machine. When these babies have matured a little the CPAP is weaned in order to allow the babies to breath without support. This trial will look at 3 methods of weaning CPAP to see which method is most efficient in allowing the babies to breath on their own. The trial has started at Westmead Hospital and we hope to include other Hospitals to increase our numbers in the trial.
